sn22.22:1.1.comm: This discourse is much-quoted in later texts of both Pali and Sanskrit Buddhism, especially in discussing what the Buddha meant by “individual” (puggala). One school of Buddhism, the Pudgalavādins, argued that the “individual” was ultimately real but not defined, being neither identical with nor separate from the aggregates. This position was rejected by other schools, including the Theravada (Kv 1.1). The text itself, however, is about spiritual responsibility, not the nature of personal identity.

sn22.22:1.2.pli: “bhārañca vo, bhikkhave, desessāmi bhārahārañca bhārādānañca bhāranikkhepanañca.
sn22.22:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the burden, the bearer of the burden, the taking up of the burden, and the putting down of the burden.
sn22.22:1.2.comm: Pali bhāra, like English “burden”, has the dual senses of “load” and “responsibility”. The opening phrase clearly indicates three of the four noble truths (the burden = suffering, picking up = origin, putting down = cessation), leaving the status of the “bearer of the burden” unclear. I propose that the sequence of the truths has been altered for rhetorical purposes, and the “bearer of the burden” is one who has undertaken the path. Compare AN 2.98–99, where the fool is the one who improperly “carries the burden” (i.e. “shoulders responsibility”), while the astute carry the burden properly.

sn22.22:1.5.eng: The five grasping aggregates, it should be said.
sn22.22:1.5.comm: Vedic skandha has no technical use, being simply the “trunk” of a tree (Rig Veda 1.32.5, Atharva Veda 10.7.38) or a person (plural = “shoulders”, Atharva Veda 6.25.2, 6.135.1, etc.). The Buddhist use shares more in common with the Jains, for whom the skandha was a type of matter (pudgala) consisting of two or more combined “atoms” (aṇu), namely a “molecule” (Tattvārthasūtra 5.5). Thus the aggregates themselves can be considered what “shoulders” the burden (like buffaloes, Arthaśāstra 2.29.8).

sn22.22:1.7.eng: The grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

sn22.22:1.8.comm: The aggregates are a “load” in the sense of being hard to bear and therefore suffering. But they are also a “responsibility”, like a wound that must be cared for if one is to heal (MN 105:19.1).

sn22.22:2.1.eng: And who is the bearer of the burden?
sn22.22:2.1.comm: Bhārahāra is attested almost entirely in discussion of this discourse. However, we do find an unrelated idiomatic use in the commentary to AN 3.91, where it means “one who takes responsibility” (for looking after a monastery). Also, Śāṅkhāyana Āraṇyaka 14.2 speaks of a student who repeats the Veda without understanding, like a pillar that merely “bears the burden” (bhārahāra), thus also referring to a person who has undertaken a responsibility.

sn22.22:2.2.eng: The individual, it should be said;
sn22.22:2.2.comm: Puggala (Sanskrit pudgala) is a Buddhist and Jain term, being absent from pre-Buddhist texts and rare later. Abruptly, the Suttas then use it some 3000 times for descriptions of “individuals” and their characteristics, especially in the Aṅguttara Nikāya, and collected in the Abhidhamma book Puggalapaññatti. Pali is rich in terms for “person”, so why did puggala became so characteristic? The Jain meaning of pudgala is “particulate matter” (Tattvārthasūtra 5.5, Isibhāsiyam 1.31, Uttarādhyayanasūtra 28.12). They say “substantial reality” (astikāya = sakkāya) includes “matter” (pudgala), which is comprised of “atoms” (anu) and “molecules” (skandha). Pudgala is also used for an individual “article” (of gold) by Kauṭilya (Arthaśastra 2.14.7, 2.14.43). Further, we find the notion that beings are pudgalāśrayāḥ (“comprised of a composite mass”, Viṣṇu Purāṇa 5.30.13) related to a criticism of those who assert not-self, i.e. Buddhists. Rarely, later Sanskrit references the meaning “body”. Thus puggala approaches the same semantic field as khandha (“aggregate”) and kāya (“body”, from the root ci, “heap”), which gives us sakkāya (“substantial reality”, SN 22.105 and notes), all three of which are technical terms in Buddhism and Jainism but not Vedism. Our findings support Paul Tedesco’s proposed derivation from pṛthak (“Sanskrit pudgala—‘body, soul’”, Journal of the American Oriental Society 67, 1947, 172–7). Given that Pali puthu combines the senses of Sanskrit pṛthu (“expansive, manifold”) and pṛthak (“separate, individual”), the original sense was probably “composite individual” (cf. English “organism”). Perhaps the Buddha favored puggala because it avoided Vedic terminology, while at the same time suggesting a connection with the khandha doctrine that the “individual” comprised a “mass” of components.

sn22.22:2.3.eng: the venerable of such and such name and clan.
sn22.22:2.3.comm: The commentary says this refers to any person from the time of birth. However, the same phrase is used at SN 22.106:1.16 and SN 23.4:2.13, both cases referring to the arahant specifically, which is why they are referred to as “venerable”. Thus the one who “bears the burden” is not someone who is reborn and has to suffer the aggregates, but someone who has full accepted the responsibility of spiritual practice in regard to the aggregates.

sn22.22:2.4.eng: This is called the bearer of the burden.
sn22.22:2.4.comm: To sum up, I argue that the “bearer of the burden” is the one who “undertakes responsibility” for practicing the path on four grounds: (1) the pattern of the teaching (four noble truths); (2) idiomatic meaning; (3) similarity to AN 2.98–99; and (4) the fact that the “venerable” phrase elsewhere refers to an arahant.

sn22.22:3.1.eng: And what is the taking up of the burden?

sn22.22:3.2.pli: Yāyaṃ taṇhā ponobhavikā nandīrāgasahagatā tatratatrābhinandinī, seyyathidaṃ—
sn22.22:3.2.eng: It’s the craving that leads to future lives, mixed up with relishing and greed, taking pleasure wherever it lands. That is,

sn22.22:3.3.eng: craving for sensual pleasures, craving for existence, and craving for nonexistence.

sn22.22:3.4.eng: This is called the taking up of the burden.

sn22.22:4.1.eng: And what is the putting down of the burden?

sn22.22:4.2.pli: Yo tassāyeva taṇhāya asesavirāganirodho cāgo paṭinissaggo mutti anālayo.
sn22.22:4.2.eng: It’s the fading away and cessation of that very same craving with nothing left over; giving it away, letting it go, releasing it, and not clinging to it.

sn22.22:4.3.eng: This is called the putting down of the burden.”

sn22.22:5.1.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

sn22.22:5.2.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato athāparaṃ etadavoca satthā:
sn22.22:5.2.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

sn22.22:6.2.eng: and the individual is the bearer of the burden.

sn22.22:6.3.eng: Taking up the burden is suffering in the world,

sn22.22:6.4.eng: and putting the burden down is happiness.

sn22.22:7.1.eng: When the heavy burden is put down

sn22.22:7.3.eng: one who has plucked out craving, root and all,

sn22.23:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the things that should be completely understood, and complete understanding.

sn22.23:1.4.eng: And what things should be completely understood?

sn22.23:1.5.pli: Rūpaṃ, bhikkhave, pariññeyyo dhammo, vedanā pariññeyyo dhammo, saññā pariññeyyo dhammo, saṅkhārā pariññeyyo dhammo, viññāṇaṃ pariññeyyo dhammo.
sn22.23:1.5.eng: Form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

sn22.23:1.6.eng: These are called the things that should be completely understood.

sn22.23:1.8.eng: The ending of greed, hate, and delusion.
sn22.23:1.8.comm: Understanding is not complete so long as delusion exists.

sn22.24:1.2.pli: “Rūpaṃ, bhikkhave, anabhijānaṃ aparijānaṃ avirājayaṃ appajahaṃ abhabbo dukkhakkhayāya;
sn22.24:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, without directly knowing and completely understanding form, without dispassion for it and giving it up, you can’t end suffering.

sn22.24:1.3.pli: vedanaṃ anabhijānaṃ aparijānaṃ avirājayaṃ appajahaṃ abhabbo dukkhakkhayāya;
sn22.24:1.3.eng: Without directly knowing and completely understanding feeling …

sn22.24:1.5.pli: saṅkhāre anabhijānaṃ aparijānaṃ avirājayaṃ appajahaṃ abhabbo dukkhakkhayāya;

sn22.24:1.6.pli: viññāṇaṃ anabhijānaṃ aparijānaṃ avirājayaṃ appajahaṃ abhabbo dukkhakkhayāya.
sn22.24:1.6.eng: consciousness, without dispassion for it and giving it up, you can’t end suffering.

sn22.24:1.7.pli: Rūpañca kho, bhikkhave, abhijānaṃ parijānaṃ virājayaṃ pajahaṃ bhabbo dukkhakkhayāya;
sn22.24:1.7.eng: By directly knowing and completely understanding form, having dispassion for it and giving it up, you can end suffering.

sn22.24:1.8.eng: By directly knowing and completely understanding feeling …

sn22.24:1.11.pli: viññāṇaṃ abhijānaṃ parijānaṃ virājayaṃ pajahaṃ bhabbo dukkhakkhayāyā”ti.
sn22.24:1.11.eng: consciousness, having dispassion for it and giving it up, you can end suffering.”

sn22.25:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, give up desire and greed for form.

sn22.25:1.3.pli: Evaṃ taṃ rūpaṃ pahīnaṃ bhavissati ucchinnamūlaṃ tālāvatthukataṃ anabhāvaṅkataṃ āyatiṃ anuppādadhammaṃ.
sn22.25:1.3.eng: Thus that form will be given up, cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.

sn22.25:1.4.eng: Give up desire and greed for feeling …

sn22.25:1.5.pli: Evaṃ sā vedanā pahīnā bhavissati ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.

sn22.25:1.7.pli: Evaṃ sā saññā pahīnā bhavissati ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.

sn22.25:1.9.pli: Evaṃ te saṅkhārā pahīnā bhavissanti ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.

sn22.25:1.11.pli: Evaṃ taṃ viññāṇaṃ pahīnaṃ bhavissati ucchinnamūlaṃ tālāvatthukataṃ anabhāvaṅkataṃ āyatiṃ anuppādadhamman”ti.
sn22.25:1.11.eng: Thus that consciousness will be given up, cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.”

sn22.26:1.1.comm: The next three discourses parallel SN 14.31–33.

sn22.26:1.2.pli: “Pubbeva me, bhikkhave, sambodhā anabhisambuddhassa bodhisattasseva sato etadahosi:
sn22.26:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I thought:

sn22.26:1.3.pli: ‘ko nu kho rūpassa assādo, ko ādīnavo, kiṃ nissaraṇaṃ?
sn22.26:1.3.eng: ‘What’s the gratification, the drawback, and the escape when it comes to form …

sn22.26:1.4.pli: Ko vedanāya assādo, ko ādīnavo, kiṃ nissaraṇaṃ?

sn22.26:1.5.pli: Ko saññāya assādo, ko ādīnavo, kiṃ nissaraṇaṃ?

sn22.26:1.6.pli: Ko saṅkhārānaṃ assādo, ko ādīnavo, kiṃ nissaraṇaṃ?

sn22.26:1.7.pli: Ko viññāṇassa assādo, ko ādīnavo, kiṃ nissaraṇan’ti?

sn22.26:1.9.pli: ‘yaṃ kho rūpaṃ paṭicca uppajjati sukhaṃ somanassaṃ, ayaṃ rūpassa assādo.
sn22.26:1.9.eng: ‘The pleasure and happiness that arise from form: this is its gratification.

sn22.26:1.10.pli: Yaṃ rūpaṃ aniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, ayaṃ rūpassa ādīnavo.
sn22.26:1.10.eng: That form is impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is its drawback.

sn22.26:1.11.pli: Yo rūpasmiṃ chandarāgavinayo chandarāgappahānaṃ, idaṃ rūpassa nissaraṇaṃ.
sn22.26:1.11.eng: Removing and giving up desire and greed for form: this is its escape.

sn22.26:1.12.pli: Yaṃ vedanaṃ paṭicca uppajjati sukhaṃ somanassaṃ, ayaṃ vedanāya assādo.
sn22.26:1.12.eng: The pleasure and happiness that arise from feeling …

sn22.26:1.13.pli: Yaṃ vedanā aniccā dukkhā vipariṇāmadhammā, ayaṃ vedanāya ādīnavo.

sn22.26:1.14.pli: Yo vedanāya chandarāgavinayo chandarāgappahānaṃ, idaṃ vedanāya nissaraṇaṃ.

sn22.26:1.16.pli: yaṃ saṅkhāre paṭicca uppajjati sukhaṃ somanassaṃ, ayaṃ saṅkhārānaṃ assādo.

sn22.26:1.17.pli: Yaṃ saṅkhārā aniccā dukkhā vipariṇāmadhammā, ayaṃ saṅkhārānaṃ ādīnavo.

sn22.26:1.18.pli: Yo saṅkhāresu chandarāgavinayo chandarāgappahānaṃ, idaṃ saṅkhārānaṃ nissaraṇaṃ.

sn22.26:1.19.pli: Yaṃ viññāṇaṃ paṭicca uppajjati sukhaṃ somanassaṃ, ayaṃ viññāṇassa assādo.

sn22.26:1.20.pli: Yaṃ viññāṇaṃ aniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, ayaṃ viññāṇassa ādīnavo.
sn22.26:1.20.eng: That consciousness is impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is its drawback.

sn22.26:1.21.pli: Yo viññāṇasmiṃ chandarāgavinayo chandarāgappahānaṃ, idaṃ viññāṇassa nissaraṇaṃ’.
sn22.26:1.21.eng: Removing and giving up desire and greed for consciousness: this is its escape.’

sn22.26:2.1.pli: Yāvakīvañcāhaṃ, bhikkhave, imesaṃ pañcannaṃ upādānakkhandhānaṃ evaṃ assādañca assādato ādīnavañca ādīnavato nissaraṇañca nissaraṇato yathābhūtaṃ nābbhaññāsiṃ, neva tāvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, ‘sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddho’ti paccaññāsiṃ.
sn22.26:2.1.eng: As long as I didn’t truly understand these five grasping aggregates’ gratification, drawback, and escape in this way for what they are, I didn’t announce my supreme perfect awakening in this world with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.

sn22.26:2.2.pli: Yato ca khvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, imesaṃ pañcannaṃ upādānakkhandhānaṃ evaṃ assādañca assādato ādīnavañca ādīnavato nissaraṇañca nissaraṇato yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ;
sn22.26:2.2.eng: But when I did truly understand these five grasping aggregates’ gratification, drawback, and escape in this way for what they are, I announced my supreme perfect awakening in this world with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.

sn22.26:2.3.pli: athāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddhoti paccaññāsiṃ.

sn22.26:2.4.eng: Knowledge and vision arose in me:

sn22.26:2.5.pli: ‘akuppā me vimutti; ayamantimā jāti; natthi dāni punabbhavo’”ti.
sn22.26:2.5.eng: ‘My freedom is unshakable; this is my last rebirth; now there’ll be no more future lives.’”

sn22.27:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I went in search of form’s gratification,
sn22.27:1.2.comm: Said also of the world (AN 3.104), the elements (SN 14.32), and the senses (SN 35.15, 16).

sn22.27:1.4.pli: Yāvatā rūpassa assādo paññāya me so sudiṭṭho.
sn22.27:1.4.eng: I’ve seen clearly with wisdom the full extent of form’s gratification.

sn22.27:1.5.eng: I went in search of form’s drawback,

sn22.27:1.7.pli: Yāvatā rūpassa ādīnavo paññāya me so sudiṭṭho.
sn22.27:1.7.eng: I’ve seen clearly with wisdom the full extent of form’s drawback.

sn22.27:1.8.eng: I went in search of form’s escape,

sn22.27:1.10.pli: Yāvatā rūpassa nissaraṇaṃ paññāya me taṃ sudiṭṭhaṃ.
sn22.27:1.10.eng: I’ve seen clearly with wisdom the full extent of form’s escape.

sn22.27:1.11.eng: I went in search of the gratification of feeling …

sn22.27:1.16.pli: Yāvatā viññāṇassa assādo paññāya me so sudiṭṭho.
sn22.27:1.16.eng: I’ve seen clearly with wisdom the full extent of consciousness’s gratification.

sn22.27:1.17.eng: I went in search of consciousness’s drawback,

sn22.27:1.19.pli: Yāvatā viññāṇassa ādīnavo paññāya me so sudiṭṭho.
sn22.27:1.19.eng: I’ve seen clearly with wisdom the full extent of consciousness’s drawback.

sn22.27:1.20.eng: I went in search of consciousness’s escape,

sn22.27:1.22.pli: Yāvatā viññāṇassa nissaraṇaṃ paññāya me taṃ sudiṭṭhaṃ.
sn22.27:1.22.eng: I’ve seen clearly with wisdom the full extent of consciousness’s escape.

sn22.27:1.23.pli: Yāvakīvañcāhaṃ, bhikkhave, imesaṃ pañcannaṃ upādānakkhandhānaṃ assādañca assādato ādīnavañca ādīnavato nissaraṇañca nissaraṇato yathābhūtaṃ nābbhaññāsiṃ …pe…
sn22.27:1.23.eng: As long as I didn’t truly understand these five grasping aggregates’ gratification, drawback, and escape for what they are, I didn’t announce my supreme perfect awakening …

sn22.27:1.24.eng: But when I did truly understand these five grasping aggregates’ gratification, drawback, and escape for what they are, I announced my supreme perfect awakening …

sn22.27:1.25.eng: Knowledge and vision arose in me:

sn22.27:1.26.pli: ‘akuppā me vimutti; ayamantimā jāti; natthi dāni punabbhavo’”ti.
sn22.27:1.26.eng: ‘My freedom is unshakable; this is my last rebirth; now there’ll be no more future lives.’”

sn22.28:1.2.pli: “No cedaṃ, bhikkhave, rūpassa assādo abhavissa nayidaṃ sattā rūpasmiṃ sārajjeyyuṃ.
sn22.28:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, if there were no gratification in form, sentient beings wouldn’t be aroused by it.

sn22.28:1.3.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, atthi rūpassa assādo, tasmā sattā rūpasmiṃ sārajjanti.
sn22.28:1.3.eng: But since there is gratification in form, sentient beings are aroused by it.

sn22.28:1.4.pli: No cedaṃ, bhikkhave, rūpassa ādīnavo abhavissa nayidaṃ sattā rūpasmiṃ nibbindeyyuṃ.
sn22.28:1.4.eng: If form had no drawback, sentient beings wouldn’t grow disillusioned with it.

sn22.28:1.5.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, atthi rūpassa ādīnavo, tasmā sattā rūpasmiṃ nibbindanti.
sn22.28:1.5.eng: But since form has a drawback, sentient beings do grow disillusioned with it.

sn22.28:1.6.pli: No cedaṃ, bhikkhave, rūpassa nissaraṇaṃ abhavissa nayidaṃ sattā rūpasmā nissareyyuṃ.
sn22.28:1.6.eng: If there were no escape from form, sentient beings wouldn’t escape from it.

sn22.28:1.7.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, atthi rūpassa nissaraṇaṃ, tasmā sattā rūpasmā nissaranti.
sn22.28:1.7.eng: But since there is an escape from form, sentient beings do escape from it.

sn22.28:1.8.eng: If there were no gratification in feeling …

sn22.28:1.10.pli: no cedaṃ, bhikkhave, saṅkhārānaṃ nissaraṇaṃ abhavissa, nayidaṃ sattā saṅkhārehi nissareyyuṃ.

sn22.28:1.11.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, atthi saṅkhārānaṃ nissaraṇaṃ, tasmā sattā saṅkhārehi nissaranti.

sn22.28:1.12.pli: No cedaṃ, bhikkhave, viññāṇassa assādo abhavissa, nayidaṃ sattā viññāṇasmiṃ sārajjeyyuṃ.
sn22.28:1.12.eng: consciousness, sentient beings wouldn’t be aroused by it.

sn22.28:1.13.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, atthi viññāṇassa assādo, tasmā sattā viññāṇasmiṃ sārajjanti.
sn22.28:1.13.eng: But since there is gratification in consciousness, sentient beings are aroused by it.

sn22.28:1.14.pli: No cedaṃ, bhikkhave, viññāṇassa ādīnavo abhavissa, nayidaṃ sattā viññāṇasmiṃ nibbindeyyuṃ.
sn22.28:1.14.eng: If consciousness had no drawback, sentient beings wouldn’t grow disillusioned with it.

sn22.28:1.15.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, atthi viññāṇassa ādīnavo, tasmā sattā viññāṇasmiṃ nibbindanti.
sn22.28:1.15.eng: But since consciousness has a drawback, sentient beings do grow disillusioned with it.

sn22.28:1.16.pli: No cedaṃ, bhikkhave, viññāṇassa nissaraṇaṃ abhavissa, nayidaṃ sattā viññāṇasmā nissareyyuṃ.
sn22.28:1.16.eng: If there were no escape from consciousness, sentient beings wouldn’t escape from it.

sn22.28:1.17.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, atthi viññāṇassa nissaraṇaṃ, tasmā sattā viññāṇasmā nissaranti.
sn22.28:1.17.eng: But since there is an escape from consciousness, sentient beings do escape from it.

sn22.28:2.1.pli: Yāvakīvañca, bhikkhave, sattā imesaṃ pañcannaṃ upādānakkhandhānaṃ assādañca assādato ādīnavañca ādīnavato nissaraṇañca nissaraṇato yathābhūtaṃ nābbhaññaṃsu;
sn22.28:2.1.eng: As long as sentient beings don’t truly understand these five grasping aggregates’ gratification, drawback, and escape for what they are, they haven’t escaped from this world—with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—and they don’t live detached, liberated, with a mind free of limits.

sn22.28:2.2.pli: neva tāva, bhikkhave, sattā sadevakā lokā samārakā sabrahmakā sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya nissaṭā visaṃyuttā vippamuttā vimariyādīkatena cetasā vihariṃsu.

sn22.28:2.3.pli: Yato ca kho, bhikkhave, sattā imesaṃ pañcannaṃ upādānakkhandhānaṃ assādañca assādato ādīnavañca ādīnavato nissaraṇañca nissaraṇato yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññaṃsu;
sn22.28:2.3.eng: But when sentient beings truly understand these five grasping aggregates’ gratification, drawback, and escape for what they are, they’ve escaped from this world—with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—and they live detached, liberated, with a mind free of limits.”

sn22.28:2.4.pli: atha, bhikkhave, sattā sadevakā lokā samārakā sabrahmakā sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya nissaṭā visaṃyuttā vippamuttā vimariyādīkatena cetasā viharanti”.

sn22.29:1.2.pli: “Yo, bhikkhave, rūpaṃ abhinandati, dukkhaṃ so abhinandati.
sn22.29:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, if you take pleasure in form, you take pleasure in suffering.
sn22.29:1.2.comm: This discourse and the next parallel SN 14.35–6.

sn22.29:1.3.pli: Yo dukkhaṃ abhinandati, ‘aparimutto so dukkhasmā’ti vadāmi.
sn22.29:1.3.eng: If you take pleasure in suffering, you’re not free from suffering, I say.

sn22.29:1.4.eng: If you take pleasure in feeling …

sn22.29:1.7.pli: yo viññāṇaṃ abhinandati, dukkhaṃ so abhinandati.
sn22.29:1.7.eng: consciousness, you take pleasure in suffering.

sn22.29:1.8.pli: Yo dukkhaṃ abhinandati, ‘aparimutto so dukkhasmā’ti vadāmi.
sn22.29:1.8.eng: If you take pleasure in suffering, you’re not free from suffering, I say.

sn22.29:1.9.pli: Yo ca kho, bhikkhave, rūpaṃ nābhinandati, dukkhaṃ so nābhinandati.
sn22.29:1.9.eng: If you don’t take pleasure in form, you don’t take pleasure in suffering.

sn22.29:1.10.pli: Yo dukkhaṃ nābhinandati, ‘parimutto so dukkhasmā’ti vadāmi.
sn22.29:1.10.eng: If you don’t take pleasure in suffering, you’re free from suffering, I say.

sn22.29:1.11.eng: If you don’t take pleasure in feeling …

sn22.29:1.14.pli: yo viññāṇaṃ nābhinandati, dukkhaṃ so nābhinandati.
sn22.29:1.14.eng: consciousness, you don’t take pleasure in suffering.

sn22.29:1.15.pli: Yo dukkhaṃ nābhinandati, ‘parimutto so dukkhasmā’ti vadāmī”ti.
sn22.29:1.15.eng: If you don’t take pleasure in suffering, you’re free from suffering, I say.”
